oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Grand Junction School

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Flags; Flagpoles; Graduation ceremonies; Students; Schools
Education - Tennessee; Education - History - Tennessee; School buildings - Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two large brick buildings comprise the campus of Grand Junction School. The two-story structure at right appears to be for classrooms, while the one at left appears to be a gymnasium or field house. A line of people, possibly in caps and gowns, marches toward the field house. An American flag flies on a pole in the center.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Department of Education Schoolhouse Photos, 1938-1942
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This all-white school in Grand Junction had 5 teachers, 5 classrooms, and about 140 students enrolled. The school was in session 160 days per year, and had class sizes between 20-32 students. The principal was A.C. Keller, Jr. According to scoring standards issued by the Department of Education, most quality standards were met during the inspection.
